reviewText:
This game made me rage quit, but I loved it!

Really enjoyed The Last Photon and highly recommend it for the price it is!

I was expecting an extremely light, easy gameplay which emphasised the story and atmosphere. A lot of recent indie titles in this price range go for theme over mechanics, and because of the subject matter I anticipated much of the same. However, either I'm just terrible (a real possibility) or this game is a genuine challenge which is rare and enjoyable.

Flip side to this is I never actually finished the game, I was playing it for a Let's Play review so I couldn't sink hours into it - resulting in a rage quit. ( Here is a link to my gameplay of this title https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=1&v=wVqgiEQoz4k ). I'm definitely going to finish the game in my personal time.

Only criticisms are a lack of game pad compatibility (which would work well in this case) and the range of music which is on loop.

But yeah, it's more than affordable so if you're looking for an addictive/challenging platformer I highly recommend you play this game!
voteText: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Yes, i'm one of those freaks who finished this wonderful game, let me resume it to you:

> Pros:
+Really good story, well planned one.
+Simple and interesting gameplay.
+Sweet music and really sad narrator voice.
+Awesome way to practice your patience,perseverance and mental sanity(no kidding)
+It only takes about 10 hours to complete the 50 levels(they are not big)
+Truly challenging.

> Cons:
-Frustrating and ruthless in all aspects.
-You can cheese some obstacles.
-Had to adjust video resolution to see the whole load screen

PS: Level 46 is pure fun

reviewText: Great game. It's simple to play because you only have left & right controls, but levels are interesting and they keep getting harder and harder, so it's definitely not boring. :) Also, it's great that we get a piece of a back story with every level, because the story is very nice and thought-through and it gives a certain depth to the game. Plus the music is awesome.\nSo, once again, great game! :)

reviewText: The 28 pence I spent for this game, thanks to a Steam coupon, made it a good deal but I still cannot recommend it, especially at the standard asking price. After the first 15 levels the difficulty suddenly increases dramatically until you rage quit after dying endlessly. Difficulty is achieved by introducing death dealing obstacles that can only be surpassed by level spammage; you cannot become a pro at this game as making it to the end of the level becomes a matter of frustrating timing and chance.\n\nTo be fair the music is good, it looks nice and I was even slightly intrigued to follow the melancholic storyline to its conclusion but I just can't. After level 20 I gave up; as if I'm going to punish myself by dragging that lone photon through another 30 gruelling levels! 30 minutes is all I've got to give to it. I suppose a penny a minute is reasonable entertainment value but if you're gonna buy it then bon voyage!
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A good platformer presents interesting, challenging obstacles, and then gives the player tight controls so the only thing getting in the way of overcoming them is the player's own skill. This game does the exact opposite: It presents ridiculously simplistic levels, but gives the player awkward, sluggish movement controls – and no control over jumping whatsoever – so that the entirety of the gameplay
date: if you can call it that, consists of fighting the control scheme as it constantly gets in the way of simply moving through levels that otherwise present no real obstacles (at least during the early levels, I didn't stick around past those). Any game where you spend more time fighting the controls than the actual obstacles or enemies is unplayably broken; I got this game for just 51 cents, and I still felt ripped off.

reviewText: I was expecting difficulty when I read the other reviews but unfortunately the difficulty comes from very sluggish controls rather than challenging mechanics. You may say this is just a form of difficulty like any other, but it's a form of difficulty that feels bad in a platformer. Responsive controls are vital and it's why I can't really recommend the game.\n\nThe game is pretty spot on otherwise: the graphics, music and story adds up to a nice atmosphere. There is definitely potential here.

reviewText:
It's a nice interesting platformer with very beautiful cute graphics. The music is soothing and fits the level design, it doesn't distract from the rythm the photon (?) is jumping in.

While you are progressing at the start of each level the narrator tells you a bit more of a story about a man named Joshua Cloud and the events of his life. It's an interesting but tragic story. Personally i find the narrator's voice soothing and also fitting to the whole game.

I bought it on sale and am very happy with the investment, i haven't finished the game yet so i can not say whether i'd feel comfortable paying full price for it.

reviewText:
Imagine a platformer where you're constantly jumping.

Now, add to that objects like spikes that move up and down at the same speed you do.
I.E. if you manage to land at the right time, which happens frequently, you are up when the spikes are up causing you to need perfect movement to get over the obstacles.
This is annoying even at early levels.

Now, make the level asynchronous. Have tons of different obstacles and platforms that have different animation lengths and no discernable pattern emerges. I.E. No jump lines up quite the same each time.

Next, make it so that death doesn't reset the stage. Just respawn while everything continues moving. The result is the offset mentioned above gets larger and larger, causing the player to basically bash themselves against the level until things happen to line up correctly.

You now have this game.

On top of all this, the bounce height seems to be inconsistant as sometimes you will make it over obstacles and sometimes you won't from similar situation.

Good idea and concept. Story was vaguely intriguing. Nothing would make me want to push on through this platformer from hell though.

Game/level design is severely lacking as the level layout seems to have been designed with the attitude of \This individual part can be passed
date: so it should all be able to be passed together.\"\n\nI bought this for super cheap with a coupon and played it for about an hour and a half. I still feel like it wasn\'t worth my money."

reviewText: Can be stressful at times, but the music's good, the story's good, the narrating's good, and it's so rewarding when you pass a level.
